reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to show love to a game developer in the making whilst also saving the planet from ancient evils? Play this and you can do both.

So this game is more of a tech demo than an actual full title but what’s here is great and for free to boot, who can complain? The combat is simple but I can see it being much more complex and in depth with some work. The attack effects, lighting effects and bomb blasts are very pretty and really add to the visual splendour.

The world looks interesting, showing some good depth and I loved the details, there’s even an Easter egg in there as well. The main character’s designed really well; I loved her clothes even if they are somewhat impractical. Boob and butt physics are also a win in my book and this game has them in spades. The enemies are pretty cool too; the heavy bomb blasting grunts in huge golden armour are my favourite. There was even an epic and tense boss battle at the end to wrap things up nicely.

All in all a beautiful if flawed “game” that is well worth your time, and as mentioned it’s free as well. Several large problems though are that it’s currently only in Chinese (a problem they are patching I hear), its length is pretty short and it has a bunch of glitches. But as mentioned for a free demo that comes with an easy 100% achievement have a go and you won’t regret it.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
Please keep in mind that these are my opinions and constructive criticisms towards the game and that they should in no way shape or form be taken as a means of offense to the developers of this game.

For a free game this has quite a few high points. But as a game in general it has many more low points. The game itself has a great idea and visual style and impliments alot of its points fairly well. The visuals are decent though you can tell most of the work was put into the main character, main boss, and large enemy models, where the smaller enemies were very lack luster in their design and could really use a bit of touching up. Thats not to say that the level designs werent good or looked bad but you could definitely tell that majority of the terrain was copy/pasted with a staircase or stack of unbreakable boxes to hide easily distinguishable features that would give it away.
Now, lets talk about combat. The combat of the game absolutely needs a few tweaks to improve the overall gameplay. The combos are very appealing, well animated and pretty but dont have much in the way of having some kind of feeling of impact when attacking enemies. By that i mean when striking an enemy they continue their own attacks and do constant damage where one would usually think they would stagger or be slightly stunned from the attacks the player delivers. The damage dealt by enemies also needs to be tweaked, when the player has to constantly break away from combat to hunt down healing items just to have their health slapped back down by what few enemies decided to persue them it really makes the game hard to enjoy as well as breaking the flow of the game. No im not saying the game is too hard , im saying that it has an artificial layer of difficulty with the enemies damage amounts, constant attacks and their ability to not be stunned. This can be easily fixed by either adding a block ability, a better escape ability, or by lowering the enemies damage, and a MUST is to add stagger for when the enemies are hit so that the player doesnt have to stop fighting just to search for the rather scarce healing objects.
The level design isnt bad for an indie game. Though the game is obviously linear by nature the areas are wide enough for you to move rather freely during combat while being narrow enough to keep the player from getting lost while trying to find health items in between fights, or sometimes in the middle of them, and has a very nice variation of styles in the areas you go. You are rarely going to find yourself in a room that looks EXACTLY the same as a previous one which is a big high note for an indie game in and of itself.
Enemy AI leaves a bit to be desired in a rather surprising way. The smaller enemies meander around and will 'try' to find a way to reach the player when they get close enough but dont really follow you if you move too far too fast, this isnt a bad thing as the smaller enemies are the main bulk of what you find but pairing this with the larger enemies who hunt you down to the ends of the earth and sport a ranged attack that can hit you twice and momentarily stun you, it doesnt make alot of sense in my honest opinion. the only thing that helps you when theyre after you is how slow they are so you at least have some breathing room when youre looking for health items, which you WILL be looking for when fighting the larger enemies no matter how hard you try.
The movement and overall speed of the player character is great, not too fast and not too slow but paced just enough to allow the player to take in the visual style and scenery of the level designs. The dash however may need a few tweaks to make sure it can be used in combat more effectively without leaving the player open to an enormous amount of attacks.
Unfortunately i cannot recommend this game in its current build if you are looking for a fully fleshed out indie game. my hope is that the devs will continue working on this game and really make it into something as awesome and fun as it feels like they were trying to accomplish. the game itself shows an enormous amount of promise and i look forward to seeing how it progresses if the devs continue working on it, which i genuinely hope they do.
RLDR; game shows great promise, but still needs A LOT of work

For a short demo by developers in the making it was suprisingly good.

The enemies seem to have basic intelligence (can't be lured super easily + ranged enemies try to maintain distance). The attack animations + projectile graphics leave you a bit of time to react but nevertheless it can be quite challenging (especially before you realise that you can destroy pots to regain health).

It's fast, it's fun and i'll definitely keep an eye on what the developers are doing in the future.

reviewText:
Right off the bat, I didn't see a settings screen on the menu.  It wasn't until I was in the actual game that I hit escape and saw the settings. I was then able to fullscreen the game.

I'm using a PS3 controller and it works great. Funny enough, the instructions didn't show up until I plugged in my controller (for attacks an specials, etc.)

Some parts don't even give you instructions (floating islands with teleporters) but the key with controllers is the left trigger to teleport to the next island.

No checkpoints. You die, you go back to the beginning.

A bug I've encountered is where I've died in the first room and ended up respawning at the one right before the floating islands.

Visuals are great, but animations and mechanics could use some works. Things like jumping look awkward. I will say though that the attack animations are fluid.

Achievements broken. The first achievement you are supposed to get was broken when they updated the English UI.

Can't read the little text boxes in the corner because they are in Chinese (grrr, 4 years of studying Chinese and I still can't read it. Although even if I could, it doesn't stay up long enough for you to read it. Literally disappears in seconds and is only initiated by combat). Translation is needed... would also be nice to keep it up for a tad bit longer.

Limited instructions and gets boring fast because this should be an early access game if the developpers intend on improving it any further.

The negative reviews are little too critical... for a free game of this magnitude, it is like an art showcase. Sure, it doesn't feel like a full game, but it is a good demo. Because of the lack of checkpoints, I probably won't continue playing much longer (I keep dashing myself off the cliffsides) but the best part is that it is FREE and as you don't waste too much time trying to beat the game, you can't really complain.

Also, I didn't even need to try to get an upshirt shot. When the character died, her skirt fluttered up graciously.

reviewText:
Basic. That's the best way I can really sum up this game. Actually, this is less a game and more a very, VERY early tech demo. Don't expect to jump in and start wailing enemies all stylish and cool, like Dante or Bayonetta. All you're really given are 3 types of attacks. One button for sword swinging, one button for kicking, and holding down the Right Trigger and pressing any of the other 2 previous attack buttons will activate a special type of attack. Even with mixing up all 3 of these attacks, there's very little combo you can do in this game, and with the animation of the game being pretty stilted, even trying to exploit something here is out of the question. You also have a dash which lets you shoot straight across for a sudden burst of speed. This is only really helpful for getting out of enemy attacks but it also serves to let you cancel any attack you're doing (Dash cancelling basically).

Enemies are as typical as it gets. Ninja mooks, gorilla-like mooks, a big dude that shoots rocket, and one big boss that's a combination of all other enemies you've encountered. Enemies don't seem to flinch when you attack them, so the entire combat experience just gets really dull, especially with how huge the environment is and how slow you run. On the plus side, I can say that the game does look really wonderful. The obvious Chinese inspired locations and theme while under the night sky looks very beautiful, which is saying something for what is pretty much a tech demo.

The only real reason I'm giving this a pass is because it's a free game, so I really can't complain. As a dude who loves action beat-em-ups like Wonderful 101 and Bayonetta, I want to look at the plus side of things, and there's definitely a lot of room for improvements with this game. I envision a lot of cool things that this game can be capable of pulling off, but that's up to the developers themselves to work on.

Give this demo a shot if you truly have nothing better to do though.
